Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Understanding the Role of Quantum Coherence in Exciton Transport and Separation in Molecular Aggregates
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical: The research component of this CAREER award explores the role of quantum coherence in exciton transport and charge separation in organic semiconductors. Organic photovoltaic devices are often made from complex nanostructures. A strategy is needed to direct excitons to and separate them effectively at the donor/acceptor interfaces. As recently demonstrated in photosynthetic complex, the interplay between the coherent coupling and incoherent exciton trapping could provide an effective way for exciton transport and separation. For molecular crystals and pi-conjugated polymers, it is well known that excitons delocalize through coherent coupling, but answers to several important questions remain unclear. For example, how will the exciton delocalization boast the exciton transport range? How does delocalization size change in an ultrafast (< 1 picosecond) timescale after photoexcitation? What are the roles of exciton delocalization in charge separation? The knowledge gap is partially due to the lack of experimental tools that can measure exciton motion with the required spatial (nanometer) and temporal resolution (femtosecond). To overcome this barrier, the PI uses both femtosecond time-resolved photoemission spectroscopy and fluorescence up-conversion spectroscopy to measure the exciton transport range, delocalization size, and charge transfer dynamics at interfaces.

Non-technical: The project addresses fundamental materials issues related to organic semiconductors. The large-scale implementation of low cost renewable energy is one of the major challenges in the 21st century. The project helps to address the challenge through exploring the mechanisms that could improve the efficiency of next generation solar cells. The education activities in this project are integrated with the research activities. For example, up-to-date research topics are incorporated into undergraduate courses. Research opportunities are provided to undergraduates as well as high school students and teachers. The PI and his students visit local schools and introduce basic science related to renewable energy to K-12 students through lectures and experimental demonstrations. Public lectures designed to increase the public awareness of renewable energy are given through adult education programs at the University of Kansas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to understand the role of quantum coherence in exciton transport and charge separation in organic semiconductors. Quantum mechanical coupling between molecules allows an electron to spread over many molecules. This phenomenon is known as delocalization. The spatial extent of the delocalization, and its impact on the photo-to-electrical conversion yield were not clear. This project was aimed to address this knowledge gap by developing experimental tools that can measure the electron transport range, delocalization size, and charge transfer dynamics with femtosecond time resolution.

Intellectual Merit - Time-resolved two photon photoemission spectroscopy (TR-2PPE) was used to measure the temporal evolution of the exciton delocalization size, and the coherent transport range of excitons after photoexcitation. These measurements showed that although electron-phonon coupling is the major factor that limits the exciton delocalization size, it can be controlled to increase the exciton transport range. Moreover, the project resulted in the first-of-its-kind measurement on mapping the evolution of the interfacial charge transfer (CT) exciton simultaneously in the time, space and energy domains. The CT exciton is a critical intermediate in the photo-to-electrical conversion process. The difficulty in converting CT exciton into free charges has limited the efficiency of organic photovoltaics as compared to its inorganic counterparts. Hence, mapping the detailed evolution of these CT excitons is necessary for understanding its role in the photo-to-electrical energy conversion process. Through our experiments, we found that the generation of free charges can be driven by entropy when the delocalized electron and hole in the CT exciton form a point-like contact. This mechanism would explain the outstanding performance of the recently discovered non-fullerene organic photovoltaics. We also demonstrated how the electron delocalization can be manipulated by changing the potential energy landscape on the nanometer scale, which illustrated the feasibility in using artificial structures to enhance the photo-to-electrical energy conversion yield. Our work resulted in 26 peer-reviewed scientific publication.

Broader Impact - The project addressed fundamental materials issues related to organic semiconductors. The experimental techniques and scientific knowledge resulted from this project were also used to understand the electron dynamics in other related materials such as 2D layered crystals, carbon nanotubes and halide perovskites. These semiconductors have been used for next generation, flexible, and low-cost optoelectronic devices. Hence, the fundamental knowledge generated by this project has significant technological impacts. The research activities supported by this project were integrated with education activities. For example, a number of up-to-date research topics, such as flexible electronics, renewable energies, optoelectronic devices and optical cloaking, were incorporated into three different introductory physics courses with large class-sizes (~ 100 students per semester). Undergraduate students taking these courses were from many different disciplines ranging from physical sciences to humanities. Moreover, the award supported the research of four graduate students and seven undergraduate students. There students were trained with state-of-the-art experimental techniques. Public lectures designed to increase the public awareness of renewable energies were given through a summer education program called Mini College at the University of Kansas. Our lab also helped to host the visit of two groups of local high school students.
